course.title: Computer Basics for Beginners
course.description: A comprehensive introduction to computer fundamentals, internet safety, and digital literacy designed specifically for women new to technology.
learningOutcomes: Identify and use basic computer components
Navigate the desktop and use common programs
Browse the internet safely and effectively

modules.title: Module 1: Understanding Your Computer
modules.description: Learn about computer hardware, software, and basic components

lessons.title: Lesson 1: Computer Components
lessons.content: Learn about the main parts of a computer including monitor, keyboard, mouse, and computer tower. Understand the difference between hardware and software.

modules.title: Module 2: Getting Started
modules.description: Master basic computer operations and navigation

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Starting Your Computer
lessons.content: Learn how to properly turn on and shut down your computer. Understand the desktop, icons, and basic navigation.

modules.title: Module 3: Using Programs and Apps
modules.description: Explore common computer programs and applications

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Program Basics
lessons.content: Learn how to open, use, and close different programs. Practice with Notepad, Calculator, Paint, and File Explorer.

modules.title: Module 4: Internet Basics
modules.description: Learn to use the internet safely and effectively

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Internet Safety
lessons.content: Understand what the internet is and how to use web browsers safely. Learn about search engines and internet safety rules.

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Organizing Files
lessons.content: Learn how to create, organize, and manage files and folders. Practice file operations and develop good organization habits.

quizzes.title: Computer Basics Quiz
quizzes.description: Comprehensive assessment of computer fundamentals, internet safety, and file management

questions.question: What is the main screen of your computer called?
questions.explanation: The desktop is the main screen where you see icons and can access programs.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a hardware component?
questions.explanation: Microsoft Word is software (a program), while monitor, keyboard, and mouse are hardware.

questions.question: What should you do when you're finished using your computer?
options: Just turn off the power switch
Click the Start button, then 'Shut down'
Close all programs and leave it on
questions.explanation: Always use the proper shutdown process to avoid losing work and damaging your computer.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a web browser?
options: To visit websites on the internet
questions.explanation: A web browser is the program you use to visit websites and browse the internet.

questions.question: Which of these is a safe internet practice?
options: Never sharing personal information with strangers
questions.explanation: Never share personal information with strangers online. This is one of the most important internet safety rules.

questions.question: You should never share your password with anyone, not even your best friend.
questions.explanation: Your password is like a key to your digital life. Never share it with anyone.

questions.question: It's okay to click on pop-up ads that promise free prizes.
questions.explanation: Pop-up ads promising free prizes are usually scams. Never click on them.

questions.question: You can create folders to organize your files on the computer.
questions.explanation: Creating folders is a great way to organize your files. You can group similar files together.

questions.question: The __________ is the main screen of your computer where you see icons.
questions.explanation: The desktop is your computer's main workspace where you can see icons and access programs.

questions.question: A __________ is a program that helps you find information on the internet.
questions.explanation: Search engines like Google help you find websites and information on the internet.

assignments.title: Digital Organization Project
assignments.description: Hands-on project to demonstrate computer skills through practical file management and internet safety research

tasks.title: Desktop Organization
tasks.description: Create and organize folders on your desktop

tasks.title: Internet Safety Research
tasks.description: Research and create an internet safety guide

tasks.title: File Management Challenge
tasks.description: Create a comprehensive file management system

tasks.title: Learning Reflection
tasks.description: Reflect on what you learned and create a skills checklist

assessmentCriteria.excellent: All tasks completed thoroughly with excellent organization
assessmentCriteria.good: Most tasks completed well with good organization
assessmentCriteria.satisfactory: Basic tasks completed with some organization

videos.title: First Steps Adventure
videos.description: Tutorial on starting and navigating your computer

games.title: Computer Parts Memory Match
games.description: Match computer parts with their names

games.title: Typing Speed Challenge
games.description: Practice keyboard skills and typing speed

certificate.title: Computer Basics Certificate
certificate.description: Certificate awarded for completing Computer Basics for Beginners course
certificate.criteria: Complete all modules and score 70% or higher on the final quiz

metadata.targetAudience: Women new to technology, career changers, digital literacy seekers
